title: Tokyo - Kamakura (Part 1)
content:
Today was a spare day in Tokyo, so I decided to make the trip to Kamakura, a smallish place on the coast about an hour south of Tokyo.

The main attraction is the giant Buddha at Kotoku-in, but there are also plenty of temples and shrines to see as well.

A few things surprised me about Kamakura and made me very pleased I spent the day there!

First was the sweets / shopping lane just off the main station - I only tried a matcha ice cream (which was actually quite tasty), but the area was filled with neat little shops and plenty of people that it just had a fun vibe to it.

At the end of the lane was Tsurugaoka Hachimangu, a fairly large temple / grounds. This was impressive enough with some large structures throughout, though it didn’t have much to set it apart from others I’ve seen.

Next I walked to the main beach, and to my surprise, it actually had a lot of sand! It was quite windy, so the water itself was choppy and uninviting, but that didn’t stop a handful of keen kite surfers from enjoying the day! And that was another surprising thing about the town - it has quite a multicultural and surf-town feel which gave it a unique charm I haven’t experienced in Japan. The town felt welcoming and laid-back while still having plenty of traditionally Japanese things as well.

The day was so filled with excellent stuff, so check part 2 for the rest!
